channel.title: Question
channel.description: What does this mean exactly? http://prntscr.com/6zgru9

item.title: Question
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“WarTusk-RSPS, post:2, topic:551272”]I am guessing it is the server sending a packet over to the client or vice versa. Like if you open up your bank server sided. it sends the packet to your client so it opens the bank interface. This is typically how a lot of cheat clients work. They open up the client packets without the source sending the packet to the client. So they can open up the bank anywhere they want, or spawn objects and stuff like that.

(please correct me anyone if im wrong that is just what I understand of it.)[/quote]
You’re pretty close.

This is a server to client packet error.
A t1 packet error means the packet doesn’t exist in the client.
A t2 packet error means the client had a problem reading the packet. This one is a bit more “tricky” as it displays a bit more information.

[quote=“peterbjornx”]T2 Message format:
T2 - , , - , , - [/quote]

The solution would be to go into the client and find the packet (Assuming for a T2 error) and make sure the data you’re sending is the same it’s expecting.
If the client expects 3 bytes, then you should be sending 3 bytes from the server. If it expects a String, then you should be sending a String. Etc.

Read full topic

item.title: Question
item.dc:creator: @WarTusk-RSPS WarTusk-RSPS
item.description:
@WarTusk-RSPS wrote:

I am guessing it is the server sending a packet over to the client or vice versa. Like if you open up your bank server sided. it sends the packet to your client so it opens the bank interface. This is typically how a lot of cheat clients work. They open up the client packets without the source sending the packet to the client. So they can open up the bank anywhere they want, or spawn objects and stuff like that.

(please correct me anyone if im wrong that is just what I understand of it.)

Read full topic
